bibl.title: Letter from W.H.W. Komp to Henry Rose Carter, June 11, 1923

div1.head: Letter from W.H.W. Komp to Henry Rose Carter, June 11, 1923
div1.opener:
I. W.
Komp.
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Box 231, Crowley, La.
June 11, 1923.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Your kind letter was forwarded to me from Memphis, and I
want to thank you for your commendation of my paper on mosquito identification.
I was not at all satisfied with it in the form in which it appeared, but
I had to cut down the number of illustrations to a minimum on account of the
expense involved, and also omitted several of the less important species which
are sometimes encountered, in the interests of briefness.

I realize that I should have figured a wing of pseudopunctipennis,
but omitted it because I had no authentic material before me, and also because
it did not occur in those regions where malaria is most prevalent. I think
that the white-ringed palpi, as noted in my paper, will be sufficient to
distinguish it from punctipennis, as this character is less evanescent than
wing-spots, which are easily rubbed off.

We have Aedes canadensis here in the South, as I have found it in
Brewton, Alabama, last year, and also here at Crowley this spring. But it
is very early in appearing (here in February), and does not last long, besides
being a woodland species. If I had had more space this easily recognized species
should have been included, along with that hard biter, Mansonia perturbans.
We have had quite a flight of this last species here in May, and it usually
attracts attention because it is such a vicious biter. Maybe when the bulletin
is revised these two and perhaps some others may be included.

Regarding your questions: I have seen, much to my disturbance, A.
quadrimaculatus breeding in a fair running stream, that also was not much
better than an open sewer. I could not control them there (this was before the
days of quick-acting Paris green) for the current would float the oil off
downstream before it could act on the larvae. Gambusia helped some here,
but they had too much else to eat to be greatly interested in wiggletails.
(2) I have never seen punctipennis breeding in a large body of water, where
where it could be said definitely that they were not washed down into it
from some stream. I asked Dr. Barber what had been his experience in this
matter, and he said he had never seen punctipennis in a large pond. We
got them here in small numbers in Crowley this spring, in small woodland
pools, some with pine needles on the bottom, but none more than ten feet
or so in diameter.

We have turned up that rare Anopheles, A. walkeri, here in
Crowley, that I rediscovered fifteen years after it was first reported
for Louisiana by Dr. George Beyer of New Orleans. My first specimens were
taken on Ship Island in the Mississippi Sound, back in 1921. We are the
first to find the larvae in nature, although Beyer bred them from eggs
in the laboratory. We hope to get enough of them to try out their malaria
carrying capacity, as this has never been determined. Last spring, as well
as for a short time this year, they migrated from Ship and Cat Islands to
the mainland in sufficient numbers to be quite noticeable at the U. S.
Veterans' Hospital in Gulfport, Miss.

I feel very gratified to think that you took time enough from your
pressing work to write me so fully concerning your data on quads and puncts,
and I want to express my appreciation of your kind remarks anent my little
mosquito identification paper.
Dr. Barber wishes me to convey his best regards to you.
With kind personal regards and best wishes, I am,
